articles.headline: A Ghost Town, Going Green
articles.snippet: Nipton, Calif., is one of many places trying to generate its own power, and maybe sell some back to the grid.
articles.abstract: Nipton, Calif., is one of many places trying to generate its own power, and maybe sell some back to the grid.
articles.lead_paragraph: NIPTON, Calif. — Gerald Freeman leaned on a walking stick on a dusty hill near the four rows of his solar arrays, talking about it like an apostle on a mission. Down the road are the eucalyptus trees he planted as a potential source of biomass. And not far away, he said, he hopes to install a hydrogen system, another source of renewable fuel.

articles.headline: As New Shipping Rules Are Studied, Another Oil Train Derails
articles.snippet: The Transportation Department said that a long-awaited package of rules aimed at improving the safety of oil transport by rail had been sent Wednesday night to the White House for review.
articles.abstract: The Transportation Department said that a long-awaited package of rules aimed at improving the safety of oil transport by rail had been sent Wednesday night to the White House for review.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the latest accident involving rail cars carrying crude oil, a CSX train derailed and erupted into black, smoky flames on Wednesday in downtown Lynchburg, Va., forcing scores of people to evacuate and causing a spill in the James River.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Bill Clinton Defends His Economic Legacy
articles.snippet: Amid charges of being out of step with income inequality, former President Bill Clinton spoke out about the impact of policies like a welfare overhaul and the earned-income tax credit — a message his wife could use if she runs in 2016.
articles.abstract: Amid charges of being out of step with income inequality, former President Bill Clinton spoke out about the impact of policies like a welfare overhaul and the earned-income tax credit — a message his wife could use if she runs in 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton, who has grown increasingly frustrated that his economic policies are viewed as out-of-step with the current focus on income inequality, on Wednesday delivered his most muscular defense of his economic legacy.

articles.headline: Changed Life of the Poor: Better Off, but Far Behind
articles.snippet: Despite improved living standards, the poor have fallen further behind the middle class and the affluent in both consumption and income, and crucial services remain unattainable.
articles.abstract: Despite improved living standards, the poor have fallen further behind the middle class and the affluent in both consumption and income, and crucial services remain unattainable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Is a family with a car in the driveway, a flat-screen television and a computer with an Internet connection poor?

articles.headline: How Not to Be Misled by the Jobs Report
articles.snippet: Dips and rises in reported job growth can come from random statistical noise.
articles.abstract: Dips and rises in reported job growth can come from random statistical noise.
articles.lead_paragraph: We obsess far too much on the Labor Department’s monthly jobs report.
articles.byline: By Neil Irwin and Kevin Quealy

articles.headline: A Complete U-Turn
articles.snippet: In a widely expected transition, the chief executive of Ford, Alan R. Mulally, will be succeeded by the chief operating officer, Mark Fields.
articles.abstract: In a widely expected transition, the chief executive of Ford, Alan R. Mulally, will be succeeded by the chief operating officer, Mark Fields.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — One of the first questions asked of Alan R. Mulally when he joined Ford Motor as its new chief executive in 2006 was what kind of car he drove.
